ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Alternating loss functions for evolution
ygData.msgSnippet: Combining N losses simultaneously and alternating between N losses are different things, just to be clear. The former tends to be called “auxiliary tasks”

Subject: Re: [neat] Alternating loss functions for evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=Yrf9QX0lpSQIiQTyuzq2pSrn0cf-OvrK9JeNpxnMfmXFOtSYZbSL

--Apple-Mail=_E22467A2-4A58-4EB1-9666-30442FFF1727
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Combining N losses simultaneously and alternating between N losses are diff=
erent things, just to be clear. 

The former tends to be called =E2=80=9Cau=
xiliary tasks=E2=80=9D in deep R when there are extra tasks in addition to =
the main task (e.g. the UNREAL agent by Jaderberg et al.). Similarly, in ou=
r connection cost technique work (Clune, Mouret, Lipson 2013 <http://www.ev=
olvingai.org/clune-mouret-lipson-2013-evolutionary-origins> and others), we=
 have a cost on connections and a performance objective. Standard regulariz=
ation (e.g. L2) can also be considered an auxiliary loss. 

Goal switching =
is about changing the goal periodically. 

Multiple goals are effectively o=
ne task and thus one loss/fitness landscape in which you can still get stuc=
k on local optima. Changing goals changes the landscape, and thus can get y=
ou off of local optima in the original/previous landscape. 

Thus the two a=
re related, but very different. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith H=
arris Associate Professor in Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial=
 Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@=
uwyo.edu <mailto:jeffclune@...>
jeffclune.com <http://jeffclune.com/>
=

Senior Research Manager (Staff Scientist)
Uber AI Labs <http://uber.ai/>

=
> On Apr 14, 2019, at 2:22 AM, pablogps86@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroup=
s.com> wrote:
> 
> Actually, similar ideas have been applied in deep learni=
ng! For example, Bert (the latest breakthrough in natural language processi=
ng) is trained on two separate tasks simultaneously (predicting masked word=
s and guessing if two sentences are consecutive).
> 
> 
> I have always rea=
d that this is an effective technique, but I guess it is a bit harder to im=
plement correctly, which explains why people don't do it more often.
> 
> 
=


--Apple-Mail=_E22467A2-4A58-4EB1-9666-30442FFF1727

	charset=utf-8
